div.head: The TEI is not (just) a schema
div.p:
The TEI architecture provides:
definitions and names for several hundred useful textual distinctions
a set of modules that can be used to generate schemas making those distinctions
usage rules (varying in their formality) for those elements
a customization mechanism for selecting, modifying, and combining these definitions
a very rich library of existing specialised components
an integrated suite of standard stylesheets for delivering schemas and documentation in various languages and formats
The TEI thus constitutes a simple consensus-based way of organizing and structuring textual (and others) resources.

div.head: Relevance of the TEI
div.p:
Why would you want those things?
because we need to interchange resources
between people
(increasingly) between machines
because we need to integrate resources
of different media types
from different technical contexts
because we need to preserve resources
cryogenics is not the answer!
we need to preserve metadata as well as data

div.head: A framework like the TEI makes good business sense

list.item: re-usability and repurposing of resources
modular software development
lower training costs
frequently answered questions — common technical solutions for different application areas

div.p: The TEI was designed to support multiple views of the same resource

div.head: Un projet imaginaire : Imaginary Punch Project

list.item: Punch est un journal comique anglais de grand renomme, qui apparaissait presque chaque semaine de 1841 jusqu'a 1992: (voir .

Nous proposons un projet de numerisation/encodage qui rendra disponible ce corpus en mode texte numerique, encode, et avec soutien de pages images integrales. Ce corpus sera destine
aux chercheurs dans les SHS
aux bibliothecaires interesses de conservation du patrimoine britannique
aux chercheurs linguistes
Est-ce que la TEI va nous aider? De quelles parties aurons-nous besoin?
chaque edition de notre journal a des identifiants (numero de tome, datation, numerotation de pages )
il rassemble plusieurs "morceaux" de texte, ou on trouve par exemple des images, des vers, du prose, entiers ou en combinaison

ces "morceaux" contiennent des unites formelles telles que
image plus titre explicatif
strophes et vers
paragraphs, listes, tables
enonces, didascalies ...
entre autre...

div.head: Structuration proposee
div.p: Nous allons considerer chaque edition du journal comme notre unite de base, notre text; on va baliser chaque morceau distingue dans ce texte comme un div element d'un type predefini (e.g. cartoon, verse, prose)

Par exemple sur la page 1, il y a deux
divisions, a savoir un dessin et une poeme:
Progress
page 2 also has two, of different types:
The enchanted castle
Correspondence

div.head: Nota : divisions ne correspondent pas exactement aux pages!
div.p: Une division peut commencer au sein d'une page (page 5 par ex) and se terminer sur une autre (page 6)
Nous allons nous servir d'une balise vide pb pour indiquer le frontiere de chaque page, qui portera un lien sur l' image numerise de la page.

list.item: TEI also provides division elements with names that indicate their degree of nesting (div1, div2 etc.) which some people prefer.
Divisions must always tessellate: once "down" a level, you cannot pop "up" again within the same division.
The heading or headings of a division are part of the division, not separate from it.
Les divisions font une tesselation complete a chaque niveau.

div.head: Attributs globaux
div.p:
TEI identife des traits quasiment universels de tout element:
identification
langue
mise en form

Les attributs globaux proposes par TEI :
xml:id fourni un identifiant unique pour l' element;
n fourni un label ou autre nom, pas forcenment unique, pour l' element
xml:lang specifie la langue naturelle du contenu de l' element, en utilisant un code standard ISO
rend et rendition fournissent des codes descriuptifs de la mise en forme du contenu de l' element

div.head: Composition des divisions
div.p: Un division peut contenir (a part d'une division plus petite)...

list.item: head (heading) : un titre
p (paragraph) : des paragraphes
list : une liste (contenant head, label, item)
table : une table (contenant row contenant cell) ...
l (verse line) : un ou plusieurs vers, facultativement regroupes dans une lg (line group) strophe
sp (speech) : un enonce dramatique avec une label du locuteur (speaker) et des p, l etc. Plus des stage (didascalies)
figure (contenant graphic, figDesc, head...)

div.head: Below the paragraph...
div.p:
Within the elements already introduced, TEI offers plenty of scope for mark-up of smaller components. For example:
boundaries, such as page, column, or line breaks
highlighting, emphasis and quotation
editorial changes such as correction, normalization etc.
names, numbers, dates, addresses...
links and cross-references
notes, annotation, indexing
graphics
bibliographic citations
words and other analyses

div.head: Usage des attributs globaux
div.p:
Le dernier vers de chaque strophe du poeme page 10 est indented:
There were eight pretty walkers who went up a hill;
They were Jessamine, Joseph and Japhet and Jill,
And Allie and Sally and Tumbledown Bill,
And Farnaby Fullerton Rigby.

div.head: Mise en valeur (highlighting)
div.p:
By highlighting we mean any combination of typographic features (font, size, hue, etc.) which distinguishes the highlighted text from its surroundings. This may be for many reasons...
to mark foreign, archaic, technical usages
for emphasis when spoken
to show something is not part of the text.. (e.g. cross references, titles, headings)
or is attributed to some other agency inside or outside the text (e.g. direct speech, quotation)
TEI provides both a generic hi tag and a large number of specific ones...

list.item:
hi (highlighted: distinction typographique, sans motif particulier)
[The rest of this communication is omitted owing to considerations of space.—Ed.]

emph (emphase linguistique)
'E won't bite yer if you buy 'im guv'ner.

title et foreign:
À propos of Oxford, it is a question whether that extremely amusing book Verdant Green is still much read by freshers.

distinct (distinction typographique avec motif linguistique)
But then I remind myself that the Russian ballet is nothing if not bizarre

div.head: Citation
div.p:
Les guillemets servent a baliser un empan de texte, pour plusieurs raisons :
q (used if the reason is unknown or unimportant)
said (speech or thought)
quote (attributed to an external source)
mentioned and soCalled (nuances of narrative status)

div.head: Interventions editorialles
div.p:
We can:
use orig to show that "dawg" is what it says, even though this is a nonstandard spelling
use reg to show that "dog" is an editorially-supplied regularisation of what it says
or provide both within a choice element to say either is a valid encoding:
...a nice little dawgdog?

div.head: Entites nommes...

list.item: name (a name in the text, contains a proper noun or noun phrase)
rs (a general-purpose name or referencing string )
title (any form of title)

div.p: The type attribute is useful for categorizing these, and they both also have key, ref, and nymRef attributes.

div.head: Examples of names
div.p:
Using type to distinguish personal from geographic names:
The scene opens at a party given by Potiphar in Venice.

Using key and ref to de-reference names:
Business done.—The Commons still harping on the Budget.
Tim Healy enlivened proceedings by vigorous personal attack on the most reckless and incapable Chancellor of the Exchequer that ever sat on the Treasury Bench. Lloyd George's retort courteous looked forward to with interest.

list.item: date contains a date and time in any format
For processing it is convenient to add a normalized version, using the when attribute
Uncertain dates and times, and ranges, can be indicated by other attributes: notBefore, notAfter, from, to

egXML.p: Sunday, a month ago, was hot.

div.head: Cross references
div.p: A cross reference is a link from one point in a text (the source) to another (the target).
TEI provides generic elements ptr and ref for this purpose. If the linking text can be automatically generated use ptr; otherwise use ref.
The source is the location of the ptr or ref; the target is specified by the target attribute, in the form of a URI reference.

div.head: Bibliographic Citations
div.p:
TEI provides special elements for bibliographic citations or references:
bibl (loosely structured)
biblStruct (standard bibliographic structure)
listBibl (encloses a bibliography)
These are typically used in preparing bibliographies, or in footnotes. But even in Punch, there are examples.

div.head: Simple bibl Example
div.p: In Punch, bibliographic citations are usually associated with a a quotation from another paper

Thecit element groups the two:
It was the time when Henry III. was batting with Simon de Montfort and his Barons. Straits Times.

div.head: Embedded notes
div.p: Notes, whether appearing in the original source, or added by an editor, can be marked using the note element.
We might use this to add biographical details to the Punch transcriptions:

egXML.p: By-the-by, it is denied that Sir Joseph Beecham Sir Joseph Beecham, 1st Baronet (8 June 1848 - 23 October 1916).... was in any way responsible for the Government's "Pills for Earthquakes," by which it was hoped to avert the Irish crisis.

div.p: note has attributes place and resp

div.head: Linked notes

row.cell: Since we have several references to the same person, it might be better to put the notes elsewhere and point to them from the names

div.note: Sir Joseph Beecham, 1st Baronet (8 June 1848 - 23 October 1916) the eldest son of Thomas Beecham (1820-1907) played a large part in the growth and expansion of his father's medicinal pill business which he joined in 1866....

div.p: ... Both Earl Beauchamp and Sir Joseph Beecham appear in the recent Honours List.
By-the-by, it is denied that Sir Joseph Beecham was in any way responsible...
Could also use specialised person element, in this case.
Elsewhere can be anywhere on the Internet...

div.head: Macrostructure
div.p: As well as the transcribed text, we have to combine metadata about each volume, and images of its pages. These are the three parts of a canonical TEI resource:

div.head: What kinds of metadata?
div.p:
For IPP and for any other comparable project, we will need a place for such information as
identification of the resource itself ("what is this thing?")
statements of responsibility ("who did what when?")
indication of source ("what was this derived from?")
publication statement ("how is this item distributed and by whom?")
declaration of encoding practice ("what do the codes we added mean?")
The TEI Header supports all these, and more...

div.head: Where did the TEI come from?

list.item:
Originally, a research project within the humanities
Sponsored by three professional associations
Funded 1990-1994 by US NEH, EU LE Programme etc.

Major influences
digital libraries and text collections
language corpora
scholarly datasets
International consortium established June 1999 (see http://www.tei-c.org/)

div.head: Goals of the TEI

list.item: better interchange and integration of scholarly data
support for all texts, in all languages, from all periods
guidance for the perplexed: what to encode — hence, a user-driven codification of existing best practice
assistance for the specialist: how to encode — hence, a loose framework into which unpredictable extensions can be fitted

div.p: These apparently incompatible goals result in a highly flexible, modular, environment

div.head: TEI Deliverables

list.item: A set of recommendations for text encoding, covering both generic text structures and some highly specific areas based on (but not limited by) existing practice
A very large collection of element definitions with associated declarations for various schema languages
A modular system for creating personalized schemas or DTDs from the foregoing
Software that transforms TEI documents

div.p: For the full picture see http://www.tei-c.org/TEI/Guidelines/

div.head: What is the TEI today ?

list.item: A set of non-prescriptive Guidelines
representing a scholarly consensus about the significant distinctions worth making when encoding a huge variety of textual materials
expressed in two fat volumes of prose and a set of detailed formal definitions

these formal definitions are also expressed in several formal schema languages:
TEI P1-P3 (1991-1999) : in SGML DTD
TEI P4 (2000) : in SGML or XML DTD
TEI P5 (2005-) in XML DTD, W3C Schema, or in RelaxNG
underlying which there is a formal model, increasingly expressed as a class system or ontology

div.p: and an active user community ...

list.item: a way of looking at what text really is
a codification of current scholarly practice

(crucially) a set of shared assumptions and priorities about the digital agenda:
focus on content and function (rather than presentation)
identify generic solutions (rather than application-specific ones)

div.head: The TEI landscape

list.item: Basic structuring of continuous texts
Diplomatic transcription diplomatique, images, multimédia, annotations...
Formal data sets : dates, named entities, events, relations ...
Paratextual and metatextual data
All kinds of linguistic and analytic data
Documentation of markup schemes
Et cetera: see

div.p: ... an encyclopaedia of encoding praxis

div.head: The TEI toolkit
div.p:
TEI is not a piece of software, but there is plenty of free TEI software around!
roma
http://www.tei-c.org/Roma for building TEI schemas "Garage"
a web service for generic conversion in and out of TEI
TEI boiler plate
web publishing system Sosol
specialised transcription tool for epigraphists
Since the TEI remains 100% standard XML, there will always be more...
